In all dharmas, being without existence, realizing one's own mind's perception, free from the two kinds of deluded thoughts, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas rely on the meaning and not on the words.

If good men and good women rely on the words, they will themselves destroy the ultimate truth and will also be unable to awaken others, falling into a succession of evil views and speaking to the assembly, not skillfully understanding all dharmas, all stages, and all characteristics, and also not knowing the chapters and sentences.

If one thoroughly understands all dharmas, all stages, and all characteristics, and is fully endowed with the meaning of the nature of the phrases, then one will be able to delight oneself with the correct joy of signlessness, and establish sentient beings in the Great Vehicle of equality.
As for all dharmas being nonexistent, etc., the Laá¹…kÃ¢vatÄra-sÅ«tra says:
Cause them to know that all dharmas are manifestations of their own minds, without external objects, and free from the two kinds of deluded thoughts of the speaker and the spoken.
And it also warns students, saying, Rely on the meaning, do not rely on the words.
If one relies on the words, then one harms the meaning. How can one cause others to gain benefits?

As for falling into evil views, etc., it means that one becomes attached to the continuity of speech and explains it to others. This is not skillfully understanding the characteristics of the stages, abodes, causes, and effects of all the teachings, as well as the meaning of the chapters and phrases.
If one thoroughly understands these meanings, then one can delight in the signless and cause sentient beings to abide in the equality of the Great Vehicle.
Great Wisdom!
Those who uphold the Great Vehicle uphold the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Pratyekabuddhas, and Sravakas.
Those who uphold the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Pratyekabuddhas, and Sravakas uphold all sentient beings.
Those who uphold all sentient beings uphold the true Dharma.
Those who uphold the true Dharma cause the Buddha lineage to be unbroken.
Those who cause the Buddha lineage to be unbroken are able to thoroughly understand and attain the supreme entry.

Knowing the supreme entry, Bodhisattva-mahasattvas always attain rebirth through transformation, establish the Great Vehicle, and with the ten powers of mastery manifest various forms and appearances, penetrating the characteristics of sentient beings' forms, aspirations, and afflictions, and expound the Dharma in accordance with reality.
The real is not different, the real is not coming or going, all false dharmas cease, this is called the real.
Great Wisdom!
Good men and good women should not grasp at and become attached to the teachings, because the real is apart from words.

This continues the above text and says, since one grasps at the Dharma of the Great Vehicle, then all ordinary and holy beings are not excluded. In this way, it becomes the true Dharma, the seed of the Buddha, and the supreme, entering the place of self-realized sages.

Having already entered, one is able to give rise to the function of transforming others, establishing the Great Vehicle, manifesting forms according to type with the ten powers and fearlessnesses, comforting those who yearn, eliminating afflictions, and expounding the Dharma of suchness.
This Dharma of suchness has no separate name, is apart from the characteristics of coming and going, and all false discussions completely cease.

However, although the principle of suchness is indeed the Great Vehicle, one should not become attached to it by following the explanations, because it is said to be true reality by being apart from words.
SubhÅ«ti!
It is like a fool who uses a finger to point at an object. The fool looks at the finger and does not understand the true meaning.
In this way, fools follow the finger of words and cling to it, never letting go until the end, and are never able to attain the foremost true meaning apart from the finger of words.
SubhÅ«ti!
It is like an infant who should eat cooked food, not raw food. If they eat raw food, it will make them go crazy, because they do not know the sequence of skillful means in cooking.
SubhÅ«ti!
In this way, if one does not skillfully cultivate non-arising and non-cessation, it will be unskillful.
Therefore, one should skillfully cultivate, not following the words like the tip of a finger.
This uses two analogies to show the characteristics of gain and loss.
The first analogy of using a finger to point at an object is a metaphor for the true meaning of words.
The second analogy of a baby eating raw food illustrates skillful cultivation of the Dharma.
However, they all have gains and losses, the principle is clear.
If one is stuck in verbal expression, one loses the foremost true meaning, like only looking at the finger and not looking at the object.

If one is not skillful in cultivation, one will not accord with the principle of non-arising and non-ceasing, like a baby eating raw food and not cooked food. If one does not go crazy in this way, it is rare indeed!
Therefore, the precepts also say, Skillfully cultivate skillful means, do not follow verbal expression.
Therefore, Mahamati!
In the true meaning, one should cultivate skillfully.
The true meaning is subtle and tranquil, it is the cause of nirvana.
Verbal expression is the combination of conceptual thoughts, conceptual thoughts are the accumulation of birth and death.
Mahamati!
The true meaning is obtained from those of much learning.
Mahamati!
Those of much learning are those who are good at the meaning, not those who are good at verbal expression.
Good meaning means not following any non-Buddhist scriptures or treatises, not following them oneself, and not causing others to follow them either. This is called being greatly virtuous and learned.
Therefore, those who wish to seek the meaning should be close to the learned, namely those of good meaning.
Those who are attached to the opposite, namely to the words, should be far away from them.
The meaning of true meaning is apart from the characteristics of words, therefore it is called subtle and tranquil.
If this principle is revealed, it is the fruit of nirvana, and if not revealed it is the cause.
If one is attached to words and does not accord with the true meaning, then one will unite with delusion and form the cause of birth and death.
However, this true meaning must be attained through the wisdom of hearing.

Moreover, it is said that being good at the meaning is not merely being very learned, but it is important to forget words and understand the meaning. If one gives rise to views according to words, how is it different from non-Buddhists?
If one is good at the meaning, then oneself and others will not be confused by external teachings. This is being greatly virtuous and learned.

Therefore, those who study the Great Vehicle should not fail to be close to great virtuous ones. Otherwise, they will not be skilled in the meaning and will fall into mere words. Therefore, [the Buddha] again admonishes and encourages them.
At that time, Bodhisattva MahÄmati, again receiving the Buddha's majestic spiritual power, said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
The World-Honored One reveals non-arising and non-cessation, which is nothing extraordinary.
Why is it so?
The causes of all non-Buddhists are also non-arising and non-ceasing;
The World-Honored One also says that space, non-analytical cessation, and the realm of nirvÄá¹‡a are non-arising and non-ceasing.
World-Honored One!
Non-Buddhists say that causes give rise to all worlds;
The World-Honored One also says that ignorance, craving, karma, and conceptualization are conditions that give rise to all worlds.
The names of those causes and these conditions are merely different.
The causes and conditions of external things are also like this. The World-Honored One's discussions with non-Buddhists are no different.
Atoms, excellence, mastery, the lord of beings, and so forthâ€”these nine things are non-arising and non-ceasing;
The World-Honored One also says that all natures are unborn and unceasing, and existence and non-existence cannot be obtained.

Non-Buddhists also say that the four great elements are indestructible, their natures are unborn and unceasing, the four great elements are eternal, and they circulate through the destinies without abandoning their own nature;
The World-Honored One's teachings are also like this.
Therefore, I say there is nothing extraordinary.
I only wish that the World-Honored One would explain the differences and why they are extraordinary and superior to non-Buddhist teachings.
If there are no differences, then all non-Buddhists are also Buddhas, because they are unborn and unceasing.
The World-Honored One says that it is impossible for many Buddhas to appear in one world, as stated above, there should be many Buddhas in one world, because there are no differences.

The above says unborn and unceasing, which is directly stated in the correct teachings, but it has not yet been distinguished why it is different from non-Buddhist teachings, therefore Mahamati again has questions about differences and similarities.
There are four difficulties in total:
First, using non-Buddhist teachings on the causes of produced phenomena as a challenge to the Buddha's teachings on the three unconditioned dharmas.

Space is precisely the unconditioned of space, non-analytical cessation is precisely non-discriminative cessation, and the nirvana of the unconditioned is precisely the unconditioned of discriminative cessation.
Second, using their causes of production as a challenge to the Buddha's teachings on the twelve links of dependent arising.
Third, using the production of subtle particles and so forth as a challenge to the Buddha's teachings on the non-arising and non-ceasing of all natures.

The nine substances are: time, direction, space, subtle particles, the four great elements, the great Brahma heaven, the excellent and wondrous heaven, the great self-existent heaven, and the lord of beings, which is the self.
Fourth, using their teachings on the four great elements as a challenge to the World-Honored One's teachings on the four great elements.
All of these compare the teachings of non-Buddhists to the Buddha's teachings, as can be seen in the text.
The Buddha told Mahamati:
I teach non-arising and non-ceasing, which is not the same as the non-Buddhists' non-arising and non-ceasing.
Why is this?
Those non-Buddhists have a nature of their own, and attain the characteristics of non-arising and immutability;
I do not fall into the categories of existence and nonexistence in this way.
Great Wisdom!

I am apart from the categories of existence and nonexistence, apart from arising and ceasing, neither a nature nor without nature, because various illusions and dreams appear, it is not without nature.
How is it without nature?
It means the self-nature of form is not grasped, because it appears and does not appear, because it is grasped and not grasped.

For this reason, all natures are without nature, not without nature. But by realizing one's own mind's perception, deluded thoughts do not arise, and one is at ease and happy, with worldly affairs forever ceasing.
In the answer, first refuting what is not so, and then revealing what is.

As for the non-Buddhists speaking of inherent nature, etc., they say that nature has its own inherent nature, like the assertion that the four great elements are permanent, taking the nature of solidity, moisture, heat, and movement to all be indestructible and unconfused, as the characteristics of non-arising and non-change. However, they also grasp and falsely conceive, and although they say it is non-arising and non-ceasing, it actually has arising and ceasing, falling into existence and non-existence.
The Buddha says, I am not like this. What I speak of as non-arising and non-ceasing is apart from existence and non-existence, arising and ceasing, and neither existence nor non-existence.
Like illusory and dream-like forms appearing, it is not non-existent, but the nature of form cannot be apprehended, so it is not existent.

As for the characteristic of form having no inherent nature being grasped, the characteristics of illusory and dream-like form are originally not truly existent. They appear due to the deluded thoughts of foolish people, but in reality they do not appear. The deluded mind grasps them, but in reality they cannot be grasped. Therefore, know that all dharmas are neither existent nor non-existent.

If one is only able to be aware that all dharmas are only mind, and there are no external objects apart from the mind, then false thoughts will naturally cease, and one will be at ease in the bliss of nirvana, forever ending the affairs of birth and death.
Foolish ordinary beings create things through false thoughts, not the sages and virtuous ones. Unreal false thoughts are like a gandharva city and an illusory person.
Great Wisdom!

Like a gandharva city and an illusory person, various beings come and go in business, and foolish people falsely think of true coming and going, but in reality there is no coming or going, it is just because of their false thoughts.
In the same way, Great Wisdom!

Foolish ordinary beings give rise to the delusion of non-arising and non-cessation, and they also do not have conditioned or unconditioned [dharmas]. Like an illusory person being born, in reality there is no arising or cessation, because of the non-existence of nature and non-nature.

All dharmas are also like this, apart from arising and cessation. Foolish ordinary beings fall into the unreal and give rise to the false thoughts of arising and cessation, not the sages and virtuous ones.
All conditioned arising and ceasing events in the world arise from deluded mind. This is what ordinary beings are confused about, so it is said not the sages and worthies.
The gandharva city is a metaphor for the unreality of false objects, as can be seen in the text.

As for the deluded person giving rise to the delusion of non-arising and non-ceasing, it means that their false thoughts are originally arising and ceasing, but they falsely take them to be non-arising and non-ceasing, which is a delusion.
They also do not have conditioned or unconditioned [dharmas]. It means that they do not abandon conditioned [dharmas], but do not know the reality of arising and ceasing;
Since there are no unconditioned [dharmas], they do not know the reality of non-arising and non-ceasing.
It is like seeing the arising of an illusory person, which is actually without arising and ceasing. All dharmas are also like this.
The reason why deluded beings give rise to false thoughts is because they do not see the principle of reality, and fall into falsehood. The sages and worthies are not like this.
Those who do not see reality are not so. The nature of self-nature and false thoughts are also not different.
If it is different from delusion, one will become attached to the self-nature of all dharmas and will not see quiescence.
Those who do not see quiescence will never be free from delusion.
Therefore, Mahamati!
The view of no characteristics is superior, not the view of characteristics.
The view of characteristics is not superior because it is the cause for receiving rebirth.
Mahamati!
For those with no characteristics, delusion does not arise. Not arising and not ceasing, I call this nirvana.
Mahamati!
Nirvana is seeing the truth, being free from the deluded mind and mental factors, and attaining the self-realized wisdom of the Tathagata. I call this nirvana.
As for not being in accordance with reality, the Laá¹…kÃ¢vatÄra-sÅ«tra says:
What is called false is not in accordance with the nature of dharmas.
Not so means not the same as the sages and worthies.
The reason sages and worthies are called sages and worthies is because they understand that delusion is precisely reality, and there is nothing else.

Just as the nature and essence of the nature of ordinary beings and conceptualization are originally no different from the truth, if one says that the truth is different from conceptualization, then one will cling to the self-nature of dharmas and not see the essence of original quiescence.
Not seeing this essence, one will never be able to depart from conceptual attachment.

As for saying that the view of no characteristics is superior, since it is said that clinging to characteristics does not see quiescence, then wanting to see quiescence with no characteristics as superior is not seeing with characteristics.
It is just that clinging to characteristics and views is the cause of birth and death, so it is not superior.
Then, no characteristics is departing from conceptualization and conforming with the unborn and unceasing, which is what the Buddha teaches as ultimate nirvana.
It is also said, Nirvana is like seeing the truth, then before seeing nirvana, the mind and mental factors of conceptualization are all completely far removed, up to the stage of buddhahood.
At that time, the World-Honored One wanted to reiterate this meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
Eliminating their theories of arising, establishing the meaning of non-arising,
I expound such a Dharma, which fools are unable to understand.
All dharmas are unborn, without nature, and non-existent,
Like a gandharva, an illusion, or a dream. Those with inherent nature are without cause.
Unborn and without self-nature, why speak of emptiness as a cause?
Because apart from the combination, the nature of awareness does not appear,
Therefore emptiness is unborn. I say it is without self-nature.
Referring to each combination, the nature appears but does not exist,
Analyzed, there is no combination, unlike the views of non-Buddhists.
Eliminating their theories of arising means refuting the false theories of those non-Buddhists.
Although non-Buddhists have the words non-arising and non-ceasing, they are conceptual thoughts and discrimination, which are the causes of birth and death, thus called theories of arising.
The Buddha said that non-arising and non-cessation are the true principle of the middle way. Since it is in contrast to existence, it is called the meaning of non-arising.
The verse below all dharmas praises non-existence and non-non-existence, like a mirage or an illusion. Although they exist, they are without causes.
Non-arising, no self-nature, etc. is a continuation of the above questioning, saying that non-arising is no self-nature, no nature is emptiness. How can it be said to be the self?
Leaving the combination... below is the explanation, saying that in the faculties and objects, leaving the combined characteristics, the nature of cognition naturally does not appear.
Not appearing is emptiness, emptiness is non-arising. Therefore, the Buddha says it is no self-nature.
Saying one... below repeats the above meaning, which can be seen in the text.
Dreams, illusions, hanging hair, mirages, and gandharvas,
The various things in the world, appear without causes,
Subduing the theories of causation, promoting the meaning of non-arising.
Expounding the meaning of non-arising, the flow of the Dharma will never cease,
Flaming with the doctrine of no cause, terrifying the non-Buddhists.

The analogies of dreams, illusions, and so forth illustrate how worldly phenomena appear without cause, their nature originally empty, both demonstrating the meaning of non-arising. What is refuted and established is the subduing of the non-Buddhists' doctrine of causation, expounding the meaning of non-arising.

However, the non-Buddhists originally conceive of arising without cause, yet speak of causation. This is because what they call non-arising and non-ceasing is actually a false conception, truly the cause of birth and death, thus they are rebuked for their doctrine of causation.
Once the non-Buddhist doctrines are extinguished, the true Dharma will spread, and the doctrine of non-arising will be spoken of in full, causing the non-Buddhists to hear and be terrified.
At that time, Mahamati asked in verse:
Why? What is the cause? Why do they also arise?
Where do they unite to make the doctrine of no cause?
At that time, the World-Honored One replied in verse:
Contemplate conditioned phenomena, not without cause or with cause,
The views of those who speak of arising and ceasing will be extinguished from this.
This verse investigates the meaning of the doctrine of causelessness through questions and answers.
The question has four meanings:
Namely, why, what is the cause, what is the reason, and where is this doctrine of causelessness made?
The answer also has four parts:
Contemplate conditioned phenomena is the answer to where. Conditioned phenomena refer to the arising and ceasing phenomena of the world;
Not without cause or with cause is the answer to how. It means the Buddha's teachings are neither existent nor nonexistent;
The views of those who speak of arising and ceasing is the answer to what is the cause. It means it is caused by the non-Buddhist teachings of arising and ceasing;
Will be extinguished from this is the answer to why. It means to extinguish that wrong view.
At that time, Mahamati spoke a verse to ask:
What is meant by non-arising?
Is it the absence of intrinsic nature?
Is it to look at various conditions?
Is there a dharma called non-arising?
The name should not be without meaning, please explain it in detail.
This question asks about the meaning of non-arising: are all dharmas without self-nature called non-arising?
Or is it called non-arising because it depends on various causes and conditions?
Or is there a separate dharma called non-arising?
Since there is the name of non-arising, there must be the meaning of non-arising. I only wish that the Buddha would explain it.
At that time, the World-Honored One again replied in verse:
It is not without nature and non-arising, nor is it looking at various conditions,
It is not with a nature and a name, nor is the name without meaning.
All non-Buddhists, Å›rÄvakas, and pratyekabuddhas,
The realm of the seventh stage, this is called the characteristic of non-arising.
In the answer, it first refutes the question. The non-arising is not falling into existence or non-existence, therefore it all refutes it.
The name is also not without meaning, and then raises the correct answer.
There are three main points:

First, it is manifested by the stage of realization. This stage of acceptance of non-arising is not the realm of ordinary beings, lesser vehicles, or biased teachings. The seventh stage refers to the seventh ground. Because bodhisattvas break through ignorance only on the eighth ground, it is said that it is not the realm of the seventh stage.
Far removed from all causes and conditions, also free from all affairs,
Only the subtle mind abides, both thought and object of thought are completely separated,
The body follows and transforms, I say this is non-arising.
Second, because it is free from all conditions, it is not a condition of concern.
Since it is free from all conditions, it is also free from all affairs of birth and death. There is only the subtle and tranquil mind.

Abiding in this way, one is able to completely separate thought and object of thought, and the deluded mind becomes the wondrous mind, while the body also becomes superior. This is called non-arising, as taught by the Buddha.
External nature is non-existent, and there is no mind to grasp,
Cutting off all views, I say this is non-arising.
Thus, non-intrinsic nature, emptiness, and so forth should be distinguished,
Not empty, therefore it is said to be empty, not arising, therefore it is said to be empty.
Third, because both existent and non-existent natures cannot be obtained, both internal and external are forgotten.
External nature is non-existent means forgetting the external, and there is no mind to grasp means forgetting the internal.

Since both internal and external are forgotten, then views of sameness and difference are cut off. Thus, non-arising is non-intrinsic nature, and because of non-intrinsic nature, it is empty. Emptiness is also unobtainable, therefore it is said not empty, therefore it is said to be empty.
Emptiness is non-arising, therefore it is also said not arising, therefore it is said to be empty.ğŸ”½The aggregation of causes and conditions, then there is arising and ceasing,
Apart from the aggregation of causes and conditions, there is no separate arising and ceasing.
Abandoning the enumeration of causes and conditions, there is no other nature.
If one says one or different, this is the imagination of non-Buddhists.
Existence and non-existence do not arise, not existent and not non-existent,
Excluding the transformation of enumeration, all are unobtainable.
This shows the meaning of non-arising in relation to dependent origination. According to the later text, the dharmas of the twelve links of dependent origination arise and cease in combination.

However, the twelve links of afflictions and karma also arise from the causes and conditions of the faculties and objects. If one leaves the causes and conditions that give rise to them, how can the arising dharmas exist?
Therefore, it is said that there is no separate arising and ceasing.
If one leaves the causes and conditions of arising and ceasing, how can there be the views of one and different, the same as non-Buddhists?

If one leaves one and different, one also leaves the four propositions of existence, non-existence, both existence and non-existence, and neither existence nor non-existence, except for those that are transformed by causes and conditions.
All who can understand non-arising cannot obtain any of the propositions of existence and non-existence.
There are only various worldly conventions, mutually becoming hooks and chains,
Apart from those causes and conditions, the meaning of arising cannot be obtained.
The nature of non-arising does not arise, free from the faults of non-Buddhists,
Only speaking of conditioned hooks and chains, ordinary fools cannot understand.
If apart from conditioned hooks and chains, there is a separate nature of arising,
Then this is a theory of no causes, destroying the meaning of hooks and chains.
Like a lamp illuminating various forms, hooks and chains manifest if so,
Then this is apart from hooks and chains, with separate various natures.

The various worldly conventions are the worldly false causes and conditions of birth and death. It means that ordinary beings from the beginning have only pursued false conditions, transmigrating in birth and death, like hooks and chains that cannot be severed.
If one can understand that the arising of false conditions is itself non-arising, then it is said that the meaning of arising cannot be obtained.

As for saying that there is no nature in arising and that it does not arise, it means that understanding that arising is non-arising, the attachment to nature does not arise, and one then avoids the mistaken views of non-Buddhists.

However, I speak of the meaning of the chain of causes and conditions, causing one to understand that arising is precisely non-arising. This is something that ordinary foolish people cannot understand.

If apart from the causes and conditions that can give rise [to something], there is a dharma that is given rise to, then I would be speaking of a theory of no causes, and would be contradicting my own meaning of the chain [of causes and conditions].

As for like a lamp revealing various forms, the Buddha means that I speak of the meaning of the chain [of causes and conditions] precisely in order to cause people to understand that arising is precisely non-arising. Otherwise, apart from this dharma of arising, if one seeks non-arising elsewhere, it is like various objects being revealed by a lamp, and not that the objects themselves are the illumination. Therefore, it says the manifestation of the chain is like that.
It means that if the manifestation of the chain is like that, then apart from causes and conditions there are various dharmas.
If one departs from the hook-chain, wisdom has nothing to discriminate.
Moreover, there is another non-arising, the Dharma attained by the sages,
The arising of the unborn, this is the acceptance of the unborn.
Penetrating the nature and characteristics of dependently arisen dharmas as unobtainable is the unborn, then its essence is like unobstructed space.
If one departs from dependent arising and separately seeks the unborn, this wisdom has no function of observation, therefore it is said wisdom has nothing to discriminate.
The other non-arising refers to what is attained by the sages above. By understanding that arising is precisely non-arising, this is the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
If one causes the various worlds to contemplate the hook-chain,
All will depart from the hook-chain and attain samÄdhi from this.
Delusion, craving, and various karmas, etc., are the inner hook-chain,
The drill and fire-sticks, the clay lump and wheel, seeds, etc. are called the outer.
If there were an intrinsic nature, arising from causes and conditions,
That would not be the meaning of the hook and chain, and it would not be established.
If arising is without intrinsic nature, for what would there be a hook and chain?
Because of mutual arising, one should understand the meaning of causes and conditions.

This means that if sentient beings in the world are able to cultivate and observe the dharmas that arise from causes and conditions, their intrinsic nature is empty, and they attain the samÄdhi of non-arising, free from the hook and chain.

However, the observed causes and conditions are internal and external. Internally, there are the twelve links of dependent origination beginning with ignorance. Externally, there are things such as drilling wood to make fire and making a wheel out of clay.
Drilling wood to make fire, making a clay pot, and a seed producing a sprout - these three are called external causes and conditions.
These external causes and conditions are used as analogies for the internal, revealing that apart from causes and conditions there is no separate dharma of arising.

If one says that there is a separate dharma that arises from other conditions, this is not a good understanding of the principle of dependent origination, and one will not be able to accomplish the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
If one realizes that arising is non-arising, then bondage becomes liberation. Therefore, it is said, For whom is that hook-chain?
Otherwise, one will revolve in birth and death, which is the principle of dependent origination.
The dharmas of solidity, moisture, heat, and movement, ordinary fools give rise to false thoughts,
Apart from the numbers, there is no different dharma, this is called the absence of nature.
These four lines say that non-Buddhists falsely conceive that the natures of the four great elements are indestructible, and take them to be non-arising and non-ceasing.
Apart from the numbers and so forth means apart from causes and conditions, to speak of the dharma of non-arising.
Just as a doctor treats many illnesses, with no more than a thousand treatises,
Because of the differences in illnesses, various treatments are devised.
For those sentient beings, I destroy their afflictions,
Knowing their superior and inferior faculties, he taught them the methods of liberation.
It is not that the faculties of afflictions are different, and thus there are various teachings;
Only teaching the one vehicle is then the great vehicle.
This metaphor illustrates the Tathagata's intention in establishing the teachings.

If discussing the original intention of transcending the world, it is only teaching the one vehicle to deliver sentient beings, like the great physician who only uses the agada medicine to universally treat all illnesses, thus saying there is no more than a thousand treatises.

However, since the capacities of beings are not equal, he cannot avoid skillfully employing expedient means, teaching the three vehicles, gradually subduing them, like prescribing various medicines according to the differences in illnesses.

However, it is not that the faculties are different and the teachings are distinct. When the conditions are ripe, they all return to the one true vehicle, which is to say, in the buddha-lands of the ten directions, there is only the teaching of the one vehicle.
At that time, the great being Bodhisattva Mahamati addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

All non-Buddhists give rise to the false imagination of impermanence. The World-Honored One also says that all conditioned phenomena are impermanent and subject to arising and ceasing. What is the meaning of this? Is it wrong or correct?
How many kinds of impermanence are there?
The names of permanence and impermanence are no different from non-Buddhist teachings. Without determining the meaning, how can one distinguish right from wrong?

Above, it was clarified that non-arising and non-ceasing are the meaning of true permanence. The non-Buddhist theories have already been refuted, but the distinction between wrong and right impermanence has yet to be discussed. Therefore, [the question] is raised again.
The question can be seen.
The Buddha told Mahamati:
All non-Buddhists have seven kinds of impermanence, which are not my teachings.
What are the seven?
Some say:
Abandoning what has been done is called impermanence.
Some say:
The destruction of form is called impermanence.
Some say:
Form itself is impermanent.
Some say:

As for the rest from beginningless [time] seeing, hearing, touching, and cognizing due to conceptual thoughts, etc., it is for the rest of deluded sentient beings who only due to beginningless [time] falling into the perfuming of seeing, hearing, touching, and cognizing conceptual thoughts, there are various forms and appearances, attached to existence and non-existence, and thus there is the mental consciousness that manifests dream events.

From the first ground, progressing to the seventh ground, seeing all dharmas as illusions and so forth, having already crossed over the conceptualized practices of the mind that are included and included in, they make the expedient means of the Buddha Dharma, causing those who have not attained to attain.
Great Wisdom!
This is the expedient means of the bodhisattva's nirvÄá¹‡a, indestructible, free from mind, thought, and cognition, attaining the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.
Great Wisdom!
In the ultimate truth, there is no sequential continuity, speaking of the pacification of the dharma of non-existent conceptualization.
This combines the above metaphor, referring to the bodhisattva seeing the arising of conceptualization, which is the metaphor of the great river of birth and death in a dream.
From the first ground, progressing to the seventh ground, seeing all dharmas as illusions and so forth, is the meaning of the expedient means of being able to cross over.

Having already crossed over the conceptualized practices of the mind that are included and included is the meaning of personally crossing over the conceptualizations of all sense faculties, sense objects, and so forth.

The expedient means of Buddhist teachings are used to enable those who have not attained to attain, thus liberating oneself and then liberating others, which is also the meaning of liberating those who have not yet been liberated.
As for the expedient means of nirvana being indestructible, it means that although bodhisattvas attain nirvana, they do not destroy the expedient means of liberating beings.

As for free from mind and thought, it means that bodhisattvas, upon reaching the eighth ground, attain the path of effortless practice, like the analogy of having realization without attainment. It also concludes and demonstrates the name of forbearance, thus saying attaining the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.

As for in the ultimate truth, it concludes and demonstrates, saying that within the absence of sequence, sequence is spoken of; within the absence of continuity, continuity is spoken of; within the false imagination of non-existence, false imagination is spoken of; within the dharma of non-extinction, the dharma of extinction is spoken of.
It is precisely because within the ultimate truth, not a single dharma can be attained, let alone sequence and continuity?
However, they all rely on the expedient means of the mind's capacity of sentient beings to transform, and within the originally non-existent, they are thus discriminated and spoken of.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
The realm of the mind is non-existent, this abode and the Buddha ground,
The past, future, and present, the buddhas of the three times have said,
The seventh ground is the realm of the mind, the eighth is non-existence,
The two grounds are called abodes, the Buddha ground is supreme.
The ground of self-realized wisdom and purity is my ground,
The place of sovereignty and supremacy, pure and wondrous adornment.
Shining like a blazing fire, the light reaches everywhere,
The flames do not destroy the eyes, the wheel of transformation pervades the three existences.
Transforming and manifesting in the three existences, some have been transformed before,
In them, the vehicles are expounded, all are the ground of the TathÄgata.
The tenth ground is the first, the first is the eighth ground,
The ninth is the seventh, the seventh is also the eighth,
The second becomes the third, the fourth becomes the fifth,
The third becomes the sixth, what sequence is there in non-existence?
The first eight lines first summarize, then distinguish.

Distinguishing means that up to the seventh ground still retains the mind's scope, but on the eighth ground there is no existence, therefore this distinction is made based on these two grounds. Distinguishing means distinguishing the differences.
Abiding means relying on.
Although there is no existence on the eighth ground, there is still abiding in concentration, only the Buddha ground is the most supreme.
The verses below on the wisdom of self-realization and purity all praise the ground of the TathÄgata.
The indestructible self means that although the light of the TathÄgata is extremely bright, it is unlike the light of the sun, lightning, etc. that can harm people's eyes when gathered.
Zhou means to flow around, referring to the TathÄgata flowing around the three realms, establishing teachings endlessly, with teachings reaching the three times.
Before refers to the past.
Vehicle refers to the Great and Small Vehicles.

Speaking of the ten grounds as being the first ground, etc., is to show their perfect interfusion without sequence. Ultimately speaking, how can there be stages in the true suchness of quiescent extinction?
Therefore, it is said, What is nonexistent has no sequence.
At that time, the Bodhisattva MahÄmati again addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

Or are they impermanent?
The Buddha told MahÄmati:
The TathÄgatas, Arhats, Samyaksaá¹ƒbuddhas are neither permanent nor impermanent.
Because both [positions] have faults. If [they were] permanent, there would be the fault of having a creator.
Permanence is what all non-Buddhists say is created.
Therefore, the TathÄgata is neither permanent nor impermanent, because permanence has the fault of being created.

If the TathÄgata were impermanent, there would be the fault of being created and impermanent. The characteristics of the aggregates are without essence. If the aggregates were destroyed, [the TathÄgata] would be cut off, but the TathÄgata is not cut off.

The previous statements about permanence and impermanence are numerous, but it is still not clear whether the Dharma realized by the TathÄgata is permanent or impermanent. From a rational perspective, how could what was previously explained be outside of this?
If it is not clearly distinguished, the confused will remain in the dark, so the request is made again for those who are still unclear.

The answer first states that what is realized is neither permanent nor impermanent. It is because what is realized transcends the hundred negations, is perfectly free from the many faults, and is different from the externalist theories, that it is said to be both negated.
If it is said to be permanent or impermanent, then both are faulty.
If the TathÄgata is permanent, then it would be the same as the non-Buddhists' theory that the self is the permanent creator.
The master refers to the self.
But the TathÄgata's permanence is without creation, therefore it is permanent yet not permanent, unlike their permanent creation which has faults.

If the TathÄgata were impermanent, he would be something produced, the same as the five aggregates, and would be characterized by characteristics. Since those characteristics are without essence, the aggregates would be destroyed and cut off, but the permanence of the TathÄgata would not be cut off.
SubhÅ«ti!
All that is produced is impermanent, like all things such as pots and clothes, which are all impermanent.
The skillful means of the requisites of omniscience would be meaningless, because they are produced.
All that is produced would be the TathÄgata, because of the nature of undifferentiated causes.
Therefore, SubhÅ«ti!
The TathÄgata is neither permanent nor impermanent.
It is said that all that is produced, such as pots and clothes, all return to impermanence, which shows that the merit and wisdom cultivated by the TathÄgata are all empty and without benefit.
If the same as what is produced, then all that is produced should be the Buddha.
Requisites refers to the requisites for the adornment of merit and virtue.
As for the nature of non-differentiated causes, it means that what the Buddha does is the same as that of all dharmas, and thus there is no separate nature of causes, therefore it concludes thus.
Furthermore, Mahamati!
The Tathagata is not permanent like space.
If space were permanent, the meaning of the self-realized holy wisdom would be lost.
Mahamati!

Just as space is neither permanent nor impermanent, it is apart from permanence and impermanence, sameness and difference, both and neither, because of the error of permanence and impermanence, it cannot be spoken of. Therefore, the Tathagata is not permanent.
Furthermore, Mahamati!
If the Tathagata were unborn and permanent, like the horns of rabbits, horses, and so forth, because of the permanence of non-arising, skillful means would be meaningless;
Because of the error of the permanence of non-arising, the Tathagata is not permanent.
Furthermore, Mahamati!
There is another matter by which one knows the Tathagata is permanent.
Why is it so?
Because the wisdom attained without interruption of the truths is permanent, the Tathagata is permanent.
As for the statement that the TathÄgata is not like space being permanent, etc., the Laá¹…kÄvatÄra SÅ«tra says:
If he were permanent, he would be like space, not dependent on causes to be accomplished.
However, the self-realized holy wisdom is the perfected manifestation of the TathÄgata's cultivated virtues, so there is no such fault.
Also, the statement that he is like space shows the double negation, being free from all propositions, so one cannot say he is permanent.

Moreover, if he were permanent, then he would be unborn, like the horns of a rabbit or horse, originally unborn, and there would be no meaning of skillful means to benefit beings, so it is said that the TathÄgata is not permanent.
Moreover, there is another matter to know that the TathÄgata is permanent. Above it says he is neither permanent nor impermanent, which is based on the perfect freedom of the nature virtues.
However, the TathÄgata's perfect realization in accordance with the nature can also be said to be permanent.
As for the uninterrupted wisdom that is attained, it refers to the unobstructed wisdom of ultimate original enlightenment.
Great Wisdom!
Whether the TathÄgata appears in the world or not, the Dharma definitely abides.
The Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and tathÄgatas abide without interruption, not abiding in emptiness, and also not realized by foolish common beings.
Great Wisdom!
The wisdom attained by the TathÄgata is perfumed by prajÃ±Ä, not by the mind, thought, and consciousness, or by the perfuming of the aggregates, realms, and sense bases.
Great Wisdom!
All three existences are born from unreal conceptualization. The TathÄgata is not born from unreal false conceptualization.
Great Wisdom!
Because of the two dharmas, there is permanence and impermanence, not non-duality. Non-duality is quiescent, because the characteristics of all dharmas are born without duality.

Whether the TathÄgata appears in the world or not... This means that the Dharma nature realized by the TathÄgata, whether there is a Buddha or not, the nature and characteristics always abide. This principle pervades everywhere, without interruption between ordinary and holy beings, thus it is said to abide without interruption.
Not abiding in space shows it is eternal, but fools are deluded and do not know it.

The wisdom attained by the TathÄgata refers to the wisdom of cultivated virtues, which is fully realized through the perfuming of prajÃ±Ä, unlike the mind-consciousness of sentient beings, which is perfumed by the aggregates, sense bases, and so forth.
It also says the TathÄgata is not born from false imagination in the three realms, but is only born from true virtues.
Two dharmas refers to the two dharmas of false birth and true birth.
However, although permanence and impermanence are spoken of within false dharmas, they have not yet reached true principle and are all impermanent.
The ultimate true principle realized by the TathÄgata is originally neither permanent nor impermanent.
But the word permanent is used with a biased intention, and the permanence realized by the TathÄgata is impermanence.
Those who do not understand this purport discriminate in words and say there is permanence or impermanence, so it is said not non-dual.
However, non-duality is precisely the principle of single quiescence. Thoroughly discussing all dharmas, they are all endowed with the principle of non-duality, thus it is said no arising of duality.
Therefore, the TathÄgata, the Worthy of Offerings, the Perfectly Enlightened One is neither permanent nor impermanent.
Great Wisdom!
Up to the arising of verbal distinctions, there is the error of permanence and impermanence.

For one whose discriminating awareness has ceased, they are free from the views of permanence and impermanence of the ignorant, and the wise are forever free from permanence and impermanence, not tainted by permanence and impermanence.

This says that the true principle realized by the TathÄgata is originally free from existence and non-existence, words and thoughts. As soon as one engages in verbal distinctions, one falls into the error of the two extremes.
For one whose discriminating awareness has ceased refers to the cessation of the path of words and the extinction of the realm of mental activity.
Only at this point is one free from all errors, thus it is said forever free from permanence and impermanence.

As for the teaching of the perfuming of neither permanence nor impermanence, it is said that discriminating both negations is also a wrong view. If one is apart from discrimination, the perfuming is also apart.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Those who lack the meaning of various conditions fall into the errors of permanence and impermanence.
If there is no discriminating cognition, one is forever apart from permanence and impermanence.
From their established tenets, there are various meanings.
Equally contemplating one's own mind's scope, verbal expression cannot be obtained.

As for those who lack the meaning of various conditions, it refers to those who are deluded and have not yet manifested the virtues of cultivation, all of whom fall into the errors of permanence and impermanence.
If there is no discrimination, one is apart from the two extremes and enters into tranquility.

From their established tenets refers to the permanence conceived by non-Buddhists and the seven kinds of impermanence, all of which are not the correct view, thus it is said there are various meanings.
If one observes one's own mind with the wisdom of the Buddha and accords with the true principle, then all conceptual thoughts and verbal expressions are unobtainable.
